metadata.title: Training, validation, and test phases in AI — explained in a way you’ll never forget | by Cassie Kozyrkov | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Training, validation, and test phases in AI — explained in a way you’ll never forget
metadata.description: If you’ve heard of validation in the context of machine learning (ML) and AI but you’re not quite sure what all the fuss is all about — validation is only one of the most important applied AI…

all_paragraphs: If you’ve heard of validation in the context of machine learning (ML) and AI but you’re not quite sure what all the fuss is all about — validation is only one of the most important applied AI concepts ever, no big deal — then here’s the analogy you’ve been waiting for. Imagine that Mr. Bean is about to take his first calculus exam…

Mr. Bean unearths the single equation he squirreled away and begins studying it for tomorrow’s exam. He’s got no other examples (datapoints) or resources to help him along and he didn’t bother to write down any explicit rules explaining how calculus works, so all he can try doing is search for patterns in his equation:

Just like an AI algorithm, his goal is to find a data pattern that he can turn into a recipe (“model”) that successfully takes him from the input on the left of the “=” to the output on the right-hand side. That is precisely what goes on during the training and tuning steps of an applied AI project (steps 6–7 in my step-by-step guide).
Training is all about making a recipe out of patterns in the available examples.
So let’s take a careful look at that example again… can we see any patterns?
Eureka! Mr. Bean found one! Just grab that 8, turn it on its side, and there’s the answer.

That recipe certainly works on this example. It fits perfectly. Congratulations! Should Mr. Bean rush straight to the exam? Based on some of the undergraduate exams I’ve graded, the answer is not obvious. But I bet that you — my dear enlightened reader — are better than that. You would prefer to do something else first if you were Mr. Bean, right?

I can almost hear you shouting all the way from here. “TRY ANOTHER EXAMPLE!!!” Exactly! The difference between you and Mr. Bean is that you’ll both try another one… but you’re smart enough to do it before the exam. In other words, in a low-stakes setting with room for redemption rather than a high-stakes one where there’s no take-backsies.

That’s exactly what validation (step 8) in machine learning is. Validation creates a safe, low-stakes opportunity for students to try their recipes on examples they haven’t studied explicitly. That’s how they get a signal about whether they’re ready for the real exam.
Validation gives your project some room for redemption.
(Mr. Bean is very lucky to have a professor like you. Thank you for sending him additional examples to try in the comfort and safety of his dorm room!)
So, Mr. Bean is about to try a new one. Let’s validate!
He turns that 5 on its side and boom! An answer is served.
Then he checks the performance against the correct answer you supplied and…
Sadly, that’s not how math works.
Mr. Bean saw how badly his model performs and he has a choice: start over or go to the exam anyway.

If he chooses to start over, he might go back to training (step 6) and search for new patterns in the data he already has (that single paltry datapoint) or he might go even further back and consider adjusting the data he’s working with (if it were me, I’d be begging you for a bunch of additional examples, which would mean going all the way back to step 2 in my guide).
Students (and ML/AI engineers) are allowed to bounce back and forth between looking for patterns and validating their new recipes as much as they like. (But don’t stay up all night studying!)
Finally, at 3 AM, Mr. Bean found a pattern that works correctly on all the validation examples you’ve given him.
You receive the following email at 3:08 AM:

I’ve discovered a recipe that works 100% perfectly on those validation examples you gave me. I’m probably the best calculus student you’ve ever had. How about we save time and I skip your exam? You can just give me my A+ while I sleep in.
Why not? By answering that, you’ll have answered why every self-respecting applied ML/AI project needs validation AND testing.
Every self-respecting applied ML/AI project needs validation AND testing.

Mr. Bean might be fooling himself into thinking that he understands those equations when he actually doesn’t. For all you know, he might have hacked together a crazy recipe that overfits, er, contorts itself to fit those specific examples he has been staring at all night. Perhaps he has just memorized all the answers and that’s his recipe — looking them up from memory. There’s no guarantee he understands anything general enough to handle new problems.
So let’s not take his word for it. A key principle in ML/AI is that we never trust… we test.
The proof of the ML/AI pudding is always in the eating.

If Mr. Bean tried to talk me into giving him a pass by telling me his recipe or “understanding”—well, that’s cute, but like all experienced applied AI folk who’ve been around long enough to get burned, I won’t trust him until he shows me how well he performs the task on new examples he has never seen before. (Though understanding his recipe can help me help him improve it, so explainability is very handy in the training phase.)
A key principle in ML/AI is that we never trust… we test.

Sure, Mr. Bean tried his best and his final recipe reflects his best understanding. That doesn’t mean he deserves to pass. Unfortunately, sometimes a student’s (or system’s) best is not good enough. Maybe his examples (data) weren’t informative enough, maybe he didn’t have enough datapoints to be able to uncover useful patterns (just one example was never going to be enough for learning how to solve limit calculus problems, sorry), or maybe his algorithm — er, brain — couldn’t find the winning recipe. Tough luck for Mr. Bean — not every student or AI system is going to succeed when the task is challenging to learn. That’s life.
So, is Mr. Bean’s best good enough? Should you give him a pass to go on to the next step (where you productionize him for mathematics in the wild) or should you delicately suggest he switch majors?
The testing phase allows you find out how well your student has learned the task.
Let’s find out by inviting him to a high-stakes exam where he will try his recipe on new examples he could not have memorized… If he fails this one, it’s game over. Good luck, Mr. Bean!
